chapter.title: Document Describing the Data Transmission and Infrastructure
chapter.para: The goal of this project is to explore and design ongoing quality control systems that would evaluate laboratories’ In Vitro Diagnostic (IVD) test coding.This document is intended to provide a detailed overview of the data transport of the required Laboratory Interoperability Data Repository (LIDR) Data Elements of clinical test results within these quality control systems.

section.title: Design Schematic
section.para: The Detailed Design Schematic is a flow diagram, encompassing each area to which the data is transported as well as the steps taken within those receiving entities.

section.title: Detailed Narrative
section.para: A detailed narrative has been developed to accompany the above scheme, breaking down the individual components of the flow into five distinctive receiving/sending systems: LIDR, IVD (In Vitro Diagnostic) Vendor, LIS (Laboratory Information System), Quality Organization and External Healthcare Entities (Interoperable patient results).

section.title: LIDR
section.para: The required data elements for the LIDR are the following:

listitem.para: Test Ordered analyte/observable (LOINC ®™)
Test Performed analyte/observable (LOINC ®™)
Specimen type (SNOMED CT ®™) at minimum
Specimen source site (SNOMED CT ®™)
Specimen source site topography (SNOMED CT ®™)
Specimen collection method (SNOMED CT ®™)
Specimen additives (SNOMED CT ®™)
Additional data elements and standards necessary to enable full laboratory data interoperability
Kit UDI
Instrument UDI
Harmonization Indicator
Units of Measure (UCUM)
Qualitative data result values should be disseminated in SNOMED CT®™
The IVD Vendor (manufacturer of the FDA approved test kit or instrument) provides the codes to the LIDR, ensuring each of the required elements are present.

The method of loading the IVD vendor provided codes to LIDR is an upload, via an API (Application Programming Interface) created by the LIDR Developer. There may need to be a separate interface for the IVD vendor to receive feedback on errors and/or check for version updates.
The LIDR developer must address the following potential gap:

Versioning of the LIDR File is required as it will be a compilation of ALL IVD Vendor’s test system and method data elements and will require updating when new testing methods are produced. As an immense entity with many contributors, it is critical that a method of managing the versions available to end users are maintained and updated at regular intervals or when emergent testing needs arise (e.g. pandemic test development).
A proposed procedure for how versioning could occur is:
Vendor creates an initial version for all its systems, methods and tests and sends to LIDR via an interface.
LIDR stores and adds to the aggregated list of vendor information and generates a version.
LIDR sends the new updated version back to the IVD vendors using a set schedule of release dates at a set frequency (1x per month, 1 x per 6 months).
If the vendor makes an update to its own tests, it updates its version and sends to LIDR to update the aggregate file.
An Emergency Release could be produced if there was a critical need but would require specific criteria to issue it.
LIDR Loads Data Elements to the Laboratory’s LIS.

The route of data movement to the LIS can be either via a download query from an LIS system or user, utilizing an API which is exposed, and allows for real-time query, or through a file export which could then be entered into the LIS manually or via an import.
The following gap must be addressed:
Both means of transport of the LIDR Elements would need to be developed by the LIDR developer.
The LIS users must be able to select the LIDR records that match their test compendium and specific methods.

The LIDR also loads to the Quality Organization Intake Interface as well as External Systems receiving patient lab test results, again, via a real-time API or file export. (See Quality Organization Data Flow and External Healthcare Entities Data Flow for gaps related to this).
LIDR receives feedback on vendor quality (Vendor Harmonization) through a quality process.

The IVD Vendor creates the records for the LIDR based on their analyzer and reagent system testmenus. This forms the backbone of the LIDR. (Please see the Required Elements list found in the LIDR Data flow description).
Thefollowing gap must be address:
The required elements of Kit UDI, Instrument UDI and Harmonization Indicator may requireinput/development from the LIDR, government entities, and standards setting organizations.
TheIVD Vendor submits the specifics of the LIDR FILE for each analyzer/test method and test result, including all required elements. The file is uploaded via an API to the LIDR
Feedback to the IVD vendor could be sent through an interface from the LIDR, to receive version updates and, systemic errors identified through the Quality Management process.

The IVD Vendor provides the LIDR elements to the Lab for the required elements for the specific analyzer or test system. In order to ensure these are maintained and updated accurately with the most recent versions, the proposal is that they be embedded in the Instrument Software.
The following gaps must be addressed:

The LIDR file must be uploaded to the Instrument. This way, the data could be stored on the Analyzer and is “pre-coded” for each analyte and included in the LIS (Lab Information System) interface specifications used for receiving orders and sending results for that analyzer.

If the analyzer could store the LIDR, there might not be a need for labs to load and store it in their LIS, except for methods that are NOT analyzer specific. The order code mapping would, however, need to be mapped to the specific order codes in the LIS.

Software updates to the instrument or test method would need to be kept current, includingthe LIDR required elements and its versioning. Most analyzers have software that can be updated routinely from the vendor, often via a direct internet connection.

section.title: Quality Organization

para.emphasis: The following assumptions are being made for data transmission to the Quality Organization:

listitem.para: Validate based on one piece of data from the LIDR – If a transmission of results from an LIS system is sent, within a format of single required data elements, these data elements can be validated by LIDR.

Expectation that the data structure from LIDR will be valid – LIDR, which will be developedby a third party, must contain the required data elements for every possible vendor/test method and test result.

section.para: The data fields that must be available can be found in the LIDR Recommended Elements section.

listitem.para: The route of data movement in this section, begins with the transport of test results from an LIS of a participating laboratory to the quality organization intake interface.
The following gap needs to be addressed:
In the ideal state the quality organization would intake data via an HL7 API Interface.
Prior to being sent onto the External Quality Organization’s Ecosystem, the data is validated and normalized, ensuring it will file successfully into the ecosystem.
Structural Validation of the data elements occurs within the quality organization intake interface.
The following gaps need to be addressed:

If it is validated within the quality organization intake interface, it requires the quality organizationintake interface to be able to receive the data elements from the LIDR. The intake interface must be designed to allow for LIDR Data Elements in a predefined format.
The LIDR Data elements load to the quality organization must be via a real-time interface.
If the data is validated successfully, it is passed to the quality organization ecosystem for analysis, metrics, and validation of the business process.
The following gaps need to be addressed:
The quality system may need to be updated to allow for the new codes and formats.

Because there are more data elements than in the current state, the quality organization likely will need a new schema and would need to adapt a system to aggregate the data in order to identify the potential vendor related errors.
If the data is not validated successfully, it routes through a Quality Management process described in a later deliverable.

section.title: Lab Information System (LIS)

para.emphasis: The following assumptions are being made for LIDR load to the LIS:

listitem.para: LIDR is loaded from a Third Party – LIDR Development and creation is being completed by a third party. Its repository needs to be able to receive requests and return a response message, ideally via an interface to a Laboratory’s LIS (Lab Information System).
LIDR Real-Time Interface – The interface would be real-time, meaning it is accessible by any lab, IVD Vendor or LIS and can transmit data between the recipient and the file.

LIDR as a reference to manually update – If a receiving system doesn’t have the capability to interface, the LIDR file can be accessed to view the required elements and queried for procedure specific definitions which can be exported for the requestor to utilize as needed.

section.para: The data elements to load can be found in the LIDR Recommended Elements document. However, these are the additional required fields (which will be unique for each lab) that must be present in the individual LIS and must be provided as part of each patient result transmission.

listitem.para: Ability to populate a Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) certificate number and its laboratory name for each test kit/specimen which identifies the actual performing CLIA certified laboratory.
Ability to record the disposition and/or quality of the test performed that do not meet the laboratory’s criteria for acceptability.
The route of data movement in this section, begins with the LIDR, which contains the recommended elements.

Via a query from an LIS System or user, the records can be loaded to the LIS, much like existing LIS systems can load and store LOINC codes, CAP Synoptic Reports, and/or manually accessed for specified procedures.
The download query can be via an API (which would need to be developed by the LIDR developer) or through a file export which can then import to the LIS.
The LAB must be able to select the records that match their test compendium and specific methods.
The following gaps must be addressed:
LIDR must be the source of truth of the most current version of Data Elements.
Because these files may be extremely large, it is critical that LIDR is developed with an interface to download the data to an LIS/EMR.

The lab must be able to load LIDR records specific to their test compendium and methods/instruments. Preferred method would be flowing from vendor to analyzer, followed by interface from LIDR to LIS and then the last method is a query to LIDR.
The LIS must be able to accept the elements even if the LIS or EMR already has the SNOMED or LOINC mapping present. (In current state, LOINC updates to an LIS/EMR may or may not be kept up to date).

The LIS may not have the capability to use formatted codes directly from the LIDR files loaded to the LIS and an LIS Analyst may need to manually build the codes into the LIS, mapping them to the correct test codes and methods. Ability to query would be necessary.
The LIS Vendor may need to create new fields to accommodate new LIDR elements.

It is recommended that the IVD Analyzers receive the LIDR records specific to its test menu, pre-installation or via an update from an interface directly to the LIDR to the analyzers Programming Software. This might relieve some work on the part of the LIS analysts to map or encode the required elements, however there is a potential that this process would create a conflict between the version on the instrument and what is loaded in the LIS.
It would be beneficial to engage a contact from the pilot lab’s Instrument and LIS Vendor to help investigate these ideas.

If the LIS Vendor could work with the IVD Vendors to preload the required elements from LIDR (in both the analyzer and the LIS), it could shift the onus from the individual lab organization to these vendors, and would assist in ensuring more accurate and less discrepant versions of the required elements and thus improving interoperability.

It is recommended that labs load only what applies to their compendium. Once loaded to the LIS, an order is placed in the LIS for a test procedure. The test order is sent to the analyzer or test method for test performance.
When the result of the test is completed, the result is transmitted from the analyzer back to the LIS whereit is reviewed by auto-verification rules or manually verified (completed) by a lab tech.
Within the LIS, the LIDR elements are applied to the results prior to being sent from the LIS to the Transmit Interface via an HL7 API.
The following gaps need to be addressed:
Depending on the LIS, there might be a need for a mapping table in the LIS or Interface Engine for sending lab test results, mapping the required elements to particular fields within the HL7 Message.
Discreet HL7 fields will need to be developed for the following data elements: UDI, harmonization indicator, specimen disposition by HL7.

The results are transmitted from the transmit Interface to external systems’ intake interface or interface engine via an API. The required elements of the results are validated for semantics against a LIDR file available to the receiving system.
The following gap needs to be addressed:
Formatting of the interface from the LIS/EHR to the quality organization, must allow results from non-patient samples.
If the data is deemed structurally valid, it is sent forward to the organization’s ecosystem. If it is not, it would be rejected by the intake interface of the receiving system.

section.title: External Healthcare Entitis (Patient Test Results)
section.para:
The data fields to load can be found in the LIDR Recommended Elements section. However, these are the additional required fields (which will be unique for each lab) that must be present in the individual LIS and must be provided as part of each result transmission.
Ability to populate a Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) certificate number and its laboratory name for each test kit/specimen which identifies the actual performing CLIA certified laboratory.
Ability to record the disposition and/or quality of the test performed that do not meet the laboratory’s criteria for acceptability.
Ability to transmit the sample demographics including a specimen identifier, collection date and time and other elements external systems may require.

listitem.para: The route of data movement in this section, begins with the transport of test results from an LIS to the transmit interface of a laboratory to another Healthcare Organization, Physician Practice EMR or Department of Public Health Intake Interface. All transmissions are via HL7 API.
Prior to being sent onto the External Organization’s Ecosystem, the data is validated and normalized, ensuring it will file successfully into the ecosystem.
Validation of the data elements occur within the Intake Interface Engine.
Thef ollowing gap needs to be addressed:
If it is validated within the Intake Interface, it requires the Intake Interface or EMR/LIS to be able to receive the data elements from the LIDR as a real-time Interface

If the data is validated successfully, it is passed to the external organization ecosystem for integration to the business process which would allow for successful interoperability of lab test results.
The following gaps need to be addressed.
The receiving EMR/LIS system may need to be updated to allow for the new codes and formats.
Because there are more data elements than in the current state, the LIS/EMR Vendors likely will need to develop a new schema.
If the data is not validated successfully, it is rejected, and error messages are sent back to the sending labs interface for error resolution and resubmission of test results.
